question: Which of the following structures is innervated by the median nerve? (Example 1)
short_explanation: The median nerve innervates forearm flexors and thenar muscles.
long_explanation: The median nerve arises from the brachial plexus and travels down the arm to innervate most of the forearm flexors and several intrinsic hand muscles. Key targets include the flexor carpi radialis, palmaris longus, flexor digitorum superficialis, and thenar muscles such as the abductor pollicis brevis. It also provides sensation to the lateral palm and digits 1-3 and half of 4.
applied_example: Compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel can lead to weakness in thumb abduction and opposition. Massage techniques can help reduce inflammation or pressure affecting this nerve path.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th ed.
text: Which of the following structures is innervated by the median nerve? (Example 1)
